title: Video Overview: The Civil War Begins

sections.narration: Welcome to our lesson on The Civil War Begins. Bull Run to Antietam (1861-1862). You'll experience this story through the eyes of Thomas, age 17, Union soldier, 1862.
visuals: Title card: The Civil War Begins

sections.section: Chapter 1: First Bull Run—The Illusion Shatters
sections.narration: I'm Thomas, seventeen years old, and I enlisted in the Union Army in May 1861. The war fever in my hometown of Cleveland was intense. After Fort Sumter fell, President Lincoln called for 75,000 volunteers. Within days, thousands of men signed up, including me.
visuals: Chapter title: First Bull Run—The Illusion Shatters
sections.key_takeaway: I'm Thomas, seventeen years old, and I enlisted in the Union Army in May 1861.

sections.narration: After Bull Run, the Union Army transformed. General George McClellan took command. He was young, energetic, and organized. "I will build the finest army the world has seen," he promised.
sections.key_takeaway: After Bull Run, the Union Army transformed.

sections.narration: Spring 1862. McClellan's Peninsula Campaign began with promise and ended in frustration. We landed over 100,000 troops on the peninsula between the York and James Rivers, planning to march up to Richmond, just 70 miles away. But McClellan moved cautiously, always overestimating Confederate strength.

After McClellan's Peninsula Campaign failed, Lincoln tried a new approach. He brought General John Pope from the West to command a new Army of Virginia. Pope was confident, even arrogant. "I have come to you from the West, where we have always seen the backs of our enemies," he announced.
visuals: Chapter title: Second Bull Run—Defeat Again
sections.key_takeaway: After McClellan's Peninsula Campaign failed, Lincoln tried a new approach.

sections.narration: September 17, 1862. Antietam. The bloodiest single day in American history. Twenty-three thousand men killed, wounded, or missing in twelve hours of fighting.
In this lesson, we explored The Civil War Begins through 5 chapters. Key concepts included: Battle of Bull Run, Stonewall Jackson, Battle of Antietam, Emancipation Proclamation.
